results.title: Arnold
results.creator_credit: Ron Headford and Ron Headford Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the familiar orators on the banks of the Yarra on a typical Sunday afternoon in Melbourne. Using still photographs, plus an actual sound recording of the orator and the interjections of the crowd, it provides an interesting glimpse of the orator and the people who gather round him. Photographer: Barrie Bell.

results.title: Army aviation
results.brief_description: The training of light aircraft pilots, members of the 16 Army Light Aircraft Squadron, at R.A.N. and R.A.A.F. stations. Instruction covers all stages from theory to flight in both fixed and rotary winged aircraft, including army applications for spotting, photography, supply dropping, evaluation of wounded and maintenance of aircraft. No other credits available.

results.title: Ariel II
results.brief_description: Deals with the history of the second international satellite and how it was developed and placed into orbit by American and British scientists in an effort to gain new knowledge about the structure of the universe. It covers research, experiments and development in Britain and assembly, testing and launching in the U.S. Produced for N.A.S.A. No other credits available.

results.title: Arid zones of Peru
results.brief_description: The work of Arid Zones Research Institute in Peru. Research on the soil, underground water, climate and farming practice in the Ica valley. How areas of desert have been brought into production, chiefly for high quality cotton. Incidental impressions of the life of the people, with a background of Peruvian folk music. No other credits available. Produced for UNESCO.

results.title: Area theorems
results.brief_description: Using animated shapes and the manipulation of models (translation and rotation) the facts concerning the area of the triangle, parallelogram and trapezium are demonstrated. An episode from the series “Vision in Mathematics”. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary students.

results.title: Area III: Barbara finds the formula
results.brief_description: A girl explores an imaginary place called Arealand where she learns the formula for the area of a rectangle: A = L x W, and meets the hectare and the square kilometre. No other credits available. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary students.

results.title: Area II: Barbara searches the squares
results.brief_description: A girl explores an imaginary place called Arealand where she learns about the use of squares in metric measurment. Demonstrates how to determine area either by counting squares of by multiplying columns by rows. No other credits availabe. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary students.

results.title: Area 1: Barbara arrives in Arealand
results.creator_credit: Agency for Instructional Television and South Carolina TV Network
results.brief_description: In a journey “through her window” Barbara ventures into Arealand for the three programs in the MeasureArea cluster. She explores the concept of area and discovers a variety of ways to determine it with trhe help of many unusual fantasyland characters. In this program Barbara learns that area is two-dimensional and that “covering” is a process to determine area. She encounters square metre, square decimetre and square centimetre. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Are you ready for sex?
results.creator_credit: Sheri Gillette Espar, Henry Mayer and Mayer Espar Productions
results.brief_description: Through dramatization and student discussions, questions concerning sexual responsibility, inter-personal communication, peer group pressure, sexual maturity, personal values, sexual intercourse, the use of contraceptives and sexual abstinence are examined. The discussion has an American cultural bias. Suitable for Mid-Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Are drugs the answer?
results.brief_description: Dr. Cole, psychologist, and ex-student of Dr. Timothy Leary, leads a classroom discussion on the reasons for drug taking, informs on the three main categories of drugs, the need for education of young people and for criminal prosecution of drug dealers. The film was made with the co-operation of three U.S. high schools and their students. No other credits available.
